• The given clinical vignette of a woman with hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus and examination suggesting a mass behind the tympanic membrane and CT image showing a mass in the region of jugular foramen makes Glomus Jugulare the likely diagnosis.
  • Glomus tumors are the most common benign tumors of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies.
  • Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IX cranial nerve.
Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page No 121, 122.

questions.text: In which procedure is the incision showed in the image used?
questions.solution:
• The incision shown is used in open rhinoplasty.
  • This procedure involves a transcolumellar incision, an incision made across the columella to lift the nasal sin, allowing full access to the underlying nasal structures.
  • This approach is used for cosmetic or reconstructive surgery. The open technique allows better visibility of the nasal framework compared to closed rhinoplasty.
Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No 485, 486.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with unilateral hearing loss. On examination, a small perforation is noted on his left tympanic membrane. What will be the left-sided Rinne's test finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient with unilateral hearing loss and a small perforation of his tympanic membrane is likely to have conductive hearing loss in the left ear, which will show a negative Rinne's test in the affected ear.
  • Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time.
  • Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows: Rinne and weber test
Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 6th Edition, Page No 23, 24.

questions.text: A patient presents with stridor after prolonged intubation. The endoscopic view is shown in the image below. What is the staging system for this condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient presenting with stridor after prolonged intubation most likely has subglottic stenosis post intubation.
  • This condition is staged by the Cotton Meyer's grading.
  • Subglottic stenosis following prolonged intubation is a narrowing of the airway just below the vocal cords (subglottic region), which can lead to difficulty breathing.
  • This condition is often a complication of endotracheal intubation due to the pressure exerted by the tube or cuff on the airway mucosa, leading to injury and scarring.
  • These patients present with stridor, dyspnea, hoarseness or changes in voice, and difficulty in breathing.


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 7th Edition, Page No 333, 334, 335.

choices.text: ldeal position for bougie insertion in emergencies

questions.text: What is true about the following position?
questions.solution:
• The above image shows the sniffing position used for intubation, which is the true statement.
  • The sniffing position is a common head and neck alignment technique used during intubation to optimize the view of the glottis for easier insertion of the endotracheal tube.
  • It is achieved by flexing the neck and extending the head, resembling the posture one assumes when sniffing.
  • The position aligns the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes to provide a straight line of sight, making the glottis more visible during direct laryngoscopy and intubation.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 2125.

questions.text: Following is the image of a normal capnograph. What is true about the Phase III?
questions.solution:
In a capnographic waveform, the plateau phase corresponds to alveolar air and plateau pressure.

The normal waveform has four different phases:
  • Phase I: Inspiratory baseline, represents the CO,-free gas from the airways (anatomical and apparatus dead space)
  • Phase II: Expiratory upstroke, mixing of dead space gas with alveolar gas.
  • Phase III: Alveolar plateau, represents CO,- rich gas from the alveoli. The last of the alveolar gas is sampled to measure ETCO2.
  • Phase 0: Inspiratory downstroke and the beginning of inspiration.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 1309.

questions.text: At what pressure does the marked structure open?
questions.solution:
• In the image, the marked structure is the adjustable pressure-limiting (APL) valve of Mapelson-C anaesthetic breathing system and it will open at the pressure of 30-40 cm H20.
  • This valve is designed to release gas when a certain pressure is exceeded to prevent excessive pressure from building up in the patient's airway.
  • The APL valve typically opens at pressures of 30-40 cm H,0 to allow for safe ventilation without causing barotrauma to the lungs.
  • This range is appropriate for manual ventilation to prevent high airway pressures that could lead to lung injury.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 603, 604.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing implant surgery for his upper limb. On giving general anaesthesia he develops tachycardia, sudden raise in body temperature and rigidity of muscles. What drug is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
• In the clinical scenario given above, the development of tachycardia and muscle rigidity soon after administration of anesthetic agents can be due to malignant hyperthermia.
  • Halothane is the anesthetic agent associated with this condition.
  • Malignant hyperthermia is a rare genetic hypermetabolic disease of the muscle. It Occurs due to a mutation of the gene for the ryanodine receptor (Ryr 1), located on chromosome 19.
  • It is an ion channel responsible for calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The symptoms develop when the patient is exposed to suxamethonium/succinylcholine or other inhaled anesthetics like halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, etc. 
  • This results in an uncontrolled hypermetabolic state with increased oxygen consumption and CO2 production, producing severe lactic acidosis and hyperthermia
Reference: 
Watt S, McAllister RK. Malignant Hyperthermia. [Updated 2023 Aug 17]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2025 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430828/

questions.text: This recovery position is appropriate for-
questions.solution:
• The position illustrated in the picture is known as the recovery position, and it is used in the management of patients who are unresponsive but with pulse present and breathing present.
  • The recovery position can help prevent complications such as aspiration and airway obstruction in unconscious individuals.
  • Additionally, it is crucial to continuously monitor the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation while in recovery and seek immediate medical assistance.
  • An unresponsive patient who is breathing spontaneously in the supine position is at risk of airway obstruction from their tongue, mucus, vomit, etc.
  • A modified lateral position is used and the following 6 principles are considered while choosing which variation of recovery position to use.
Online Reference: https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/first-aid/recovery-position/#:~:text=Use%20your%20free%20hand%20to,is%20at%20a%20right%20angle.

questions.text: What is the procedure being done in the image?
questions.solution:
• The position in the image of a hand with a tourniquet occluded limb shows a Bier Block.
  • IVRA or Bier' s block involves the intravenous administration of a local anesthetic into a tourniquet-occluded limb.
  • It is used to provide anesthesia for short surgical procedures (<90 minutes) on the limbs.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 1463.

choices.text: Admit the patient and aggressive debridement and antibiotics
Rest the limb, non weight bearing splints and foot care

questions.text: A 66-year-old treated leprosy patient came with complaints of a well-demarcated, non-tender ulcer on his foot with hyperkeratotic borders as given below for the last 3 months. What should be the appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image indicate a neuropathic ulcer.
This can be managed by limb rest, utilising non-weight-bearing splints, and administering foot care.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 28.13, 28.17.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had patches of partial hair loss with mild itching and scales. Family History of Similar illness is there. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patchy hair loss and multiple black dots within the areas of alopecia along with fine scaling and itching of the scalp point towards the diagnosis of tinea capitis.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 32.38, 32.39.

questions.text: A middle aged man comes with complaints of painless progressively enlarging lesions on his scalp and perianal region for the last 2 months. He has had liver and kidney transplant 2 years back and is on Mycophenolate Mofetil, Tacrolimus and Prednisolone for his immunosupression. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical scenario of painless progressive nodular, ulcerated lesions in an immuno- compromised patient with the clinical image showing yellow-erythematous-purple plaque and histopathology image showing Michaelis Gutmann bodies are consistent with the diagnosis of cutaneous malakoplakia.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 955, 957.

questions.text: Which of the following causes the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows numerous fungal spores within the hair shaft suggestive of endothrix type of tinea capitis, which is caused by Trichophyton tonsurans.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 32.38.

questions.text: A man presents with multiple lesions on his face, diagnosed as acne vulgaris. Which of the following is the most effective treatment for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The presence of multiple nodular and cystic lesions over the face and upper back implies that this is a case of acne vulgaris.
Systemic Isotretinoin is the most effective treatment for acne.

Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 90.37.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes with vesicular eruptions in the buccal mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is done and the image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows a characteristic fish- net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris.
  • This pattern is due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of lgG and C3.
  • Direct or indirect immunofluorescence cannot be used to differentiate between pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus, as they present similarly.
Online Reference: Shetty VM, Subramaniam K, Rao R. Utility of immunofluorescence in dermatology. Indian Dermatol Online J. 2017 Jan-Feb;8(1):1-8. doi: 10.4103/2229-5178.198774. PMID: 28217464; PMCID: PMC5297263.

choices.text: Start her on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors

questions.text: A 20 years old girl was referred to the psychiatry department by the Burn and plastic surgery Department. She had visited multiple plastic surgery departments requesting full facial reconstruction. She complains of dark blemishes and spots on her face, which are not present. She always says about low self esteem that she is ugly and looks constantly in the mirror. Her mother assured her of no such issues, but still, she persists in getting the surgery. What should the psychiatrist do?
questions.solution:
• The given history suggests the presence of body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) in the patient, as she is preoccupied with her appearance and self-perceived flaws, despite being told otherwise by her family.
  • The psychiatrist should start her on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors(SSRI).
  • BDD is characterized by persistent preoccupations about one or more perceived defects or flaws in one' s appearance, but the defects or flaws are negligible or not even observable to others.
  • In response to their appearance concerns, individuals with BDD demonstrate a range of mental acts: Comparing themselves with others Checking in the mirror Camouflaging their perceived flaws Avoidance- from minor social avoidance to being housebound.
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 426, 428, 429.

questions.text:
A 23 years old girl presented with multiple episodes of loss of consciousness. She regains consciousness after 15 to 30 minutes and usually remembers the events during these episodes. There is no history of tongue bite urinary or Bowel incontinence. What should be done in this scenario?

1. Initiate aversion therapy
2. Give valproate 

3. Start on ketogenic diet
4. Start behavioural therapy
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the girl is experiencing episodes of loss of consciousness that may suggest conversion disorder.
  • The most appropriate management is to start behavioural therapy to help address her symptoms and underlying stressors.
  • Conversion disorder, also referred to as functional neurological symptom disorder.
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 473.

questions.text: If a child with ADHD goes untreated into adolescence, what is he most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
• If a child with ADHD goes untreated into adolescence, among the following options he is most likely to develop conduct disorder.
  • The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may sometimes disappear, but the decreased attention span and impulse- control problems usually persist.
  • Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to conduct disorder, antisocial behaviour, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 1169, 1170, 1178.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic met with a RTA. His blood alcohol level is >300 mg/dl. The drug that will be used to manage his withdrawal symptoms is:
questions.solution:
• The first-line drug used in the management of this patient's withdrawal symptoms is intravenous lorazepam.
  • Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs usually within 3 -4 days of alcohol withdrawal.
  • Acute infection, hepatitis and pancreatitis predispose delirium tremens.
  • Clinically, patients present with confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of Counciousness.
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 629, 631, 632.

questions.text: A 35 years old male suffered a head injury from a road traffic accident. On examination, there is elevated intracranial pressure. Which diuretic among the following can be used in her condition?
questions.solution:
• In this patient with raised intracranial pressure after a road traffic accident, mannitol is the diuretic of choice in her management to reduce intracranial pressure.
  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that draws fluid out of the brain tissue and into the bloodstream as it forms a hypertonic solution when it reaches the bloodstream, thereby reducing intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • It is commonly used in cases of traumatic brain injury or other conditions that cause elevated ICP.
  • This effect helps to relieve pressure on the brain, preventing further damage. 
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition, Page No 44, 45.

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl child came agitated to the emergency department after consuming some drug with a previous history of suicidal tendencies. She presented with tachycardia, tachypnea, diaphoresis, and dilated pupils. What is the likely drug administered?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presenting with tachycardia, tachypnea, diaphoresis, and dilated pupils after consuming some drug with a previous history of suicidal tendencies points towards a diagnosis of cocaine toxicity leading to sympathetic toxidrome. Cocaine is a CNS stimulant obtained from coca.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33rd Edition, Page No 602, 603, 604.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with seizures which subsided with injection Midazolam. Blood investigations and lumbar puncture studies were normal. MRI is done and the image is given below. What is the next best investigation of choice for further assessment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a child along with an MRI showing a ring-enhancing intra axial lesion of the brain could likely be a tuberculoma or neurocysticercosis and MR spectroscopy would be the next best investigation for further assessment.


Reference: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnosis Radiology, 7th Edition, Page No 1376, 1413.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the given CT Scan.
questions.solution:
Moderate Hydronephrosis OT the affected kidney indicating a likely diagnosis of ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJ) of the left side. PUJ obstruction refers to a blockage or narrowing at the junction where the renal pelvis transitions into the ureter, leading to impaired drainage of urine from the kidney.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 281.

questions.text: A 16-year-old presented to the psychiatry OPD. He has a charming persona and is well-composed and behaved in front of interviewers. His mother complains of him getting into fights and bunking classes, drinking alcohol and getting involved in police cases. What kind of personality disorder does he have?
questions.solution:
• The patient most likely has antisocial personality disorder.
  • Although the patient seems charming and well composed, he is aggressive and clearly exhibits disregard for social norms, and shows no remorse for his actions.
  • These findings are characteristic of antisocial personality disorder.
  • Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a long-term pattern of manipulation
Online Reference: Fisher KA, Torrico TJ, Hany M. Antisocial Personality Disorder. [Updated 2024 Feb 29]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2025 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546673/

questions.text: What does this image below indicate?
questions.solution:
The given MRCP image showing saccular dilatation of the common bile duct suggests a diagnosis of type I choledochal cyst.
* Todani classification: 
  1. Type I- saccular dilatation of the whole (la) or a segment (b) of the common bile duct (CBD)
  2. Type Il- diverticulum from the CBD
  3. Type llI- choledochocele that opens into the duodenum
  4. Type IV- multiple cysts (both intrahepatic and extrahepatic)
  5. Type V- multiple cysts that are only intrahepatic (Caroli's disease)
Reference: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnosis Radiology, 7th Edition, Page No 1839.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image:
questions.solution:
As the given image shows, there are multiple calcifications within the region of the pancreas, which is characteristic of chronic calcific pancreatitis.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2666, 2667.

questions.text: What is the Structure Marked with 1 in the following using the radiological image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Superior Vena cava.

Reference: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnosis Radiology, 7th Edition, Page No 404.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child fell down the stairs. An Xray was done. ldentify the structure injured as marked in the X-ray.
questions.solution:
• The given X-ray points towards the tibial tuberosity. This image shows an avulsion fracture of the tibial tuberosity.
  • The tibial tuberosity is a bony prominence located on the anterior part of the tibia, just below the knee.
  • It is the attachment point for the patellar tendon. Injury to the tibial tuberosity is common in adolescents, especially those involved in sports or after trauma like a fall.
Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 924.

questions.text: A child sustained a fracture after a fall. An X-ray taken after fracture plating. By which of the following mechanisms will fracture healing occur?
questions.solution:
In this child with a fracture, the primary callus is the mechanism by which healing occurs.


Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 6th Edition, Page No 9, 11.

questions.text: A 56-year-old lady presents with a pathological fracture of the hip and femur. Her serum calcium and phosphate are increased. DEXA scan confirms decreased bone density. Which of the following parameters will increase in this condition?
questions.solution:
• In this patient, the pathological fracture and elevated serum calcium and phosphate suggest a possible metabolic bone disease such as Paget' s disease of bone.
  • The parameter likely to be increased is TRAP (tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase), which is a marker of osteoclast activity.
  • TRAP is an enzyme produced by osteoclasts, which are cells responsible for bone resorption. 
DEXA stands for (Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) which is used to assess your bone density and well as your body composition. DEXA uses an x-ray technique to look at the density of the body and can then estimate the amount of lean muscle mass and fat tissue.
A person can have a lot of muscle, but be considered “over-weight” by many height/weight charts. The opposite can also be true – a person can have a lot of fat and little muscle and be “over-fat” but not overweight.



Reference: Krugh M, Langaker MD. Dual-Energy X-Ray Absorptiometry. [Updated 2024 May 20]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2025 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519042/

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient with a history of a fracture. On removal of the cast, the following deformity was seen. What is the most likely cause of this deformity?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows cubitus varus deformity, where the forearm has deviated medially in relation to the upper arm, which is a common complication of supracondylar humeral fracture.
  • Malunion is the commonest complication of a Supracondylar fracture and results in a cubitus varus deformity, also known as gunstock deformity.
  • This occurs when the fracture unites with the distal fragment tilted medially and in internal rotation.

Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 5h Edition, Page No 101, 102.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presented in Ortho OPD with chronic LBP. MRI of the lower back shows the following findings. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
• The above clinical scenario, the history and MRI scan are suggestive of spondylolisthesis.
  • Spondylolisthesis is the anterior displacement of a vertebra over another, usually at the lower lumbar spine.
  • Occasionally, the displacement is backward (retrolisthesis). It is characterized by chronic back pain, lumbar lordosis, and step sign.
  • Normally, spinous processes of adjacent vertebrae can be palpated on the back smoothly. In spondylolisthesis, a step-off or step sign can be felt over the spinous process at the affected level.


Online Referenece:Studnicka K, Ampat G. Lumbosacral Spondylolisthesis. [Updated 2023 Jul 22]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2025 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK560679/

questions.text: A fracture line passing through which of these will impair longitudinal growth of the bone?
questions.solution:
• A fracture line passing through the epiphyseal plate (also known as the growth plate) will impair the longitudinal growth of the bone.
  • The epiphyseal plate is the area of growing tissue near the ends of the long bones in children and adolescents.
  • It is responsible for bone lengthening (longitudinal growth). If the fracture involves the epiphyseal plate, it can disrupt this process and lead to growth disturbances or deformities. 


Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 785.

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral three-and-a-half fingers on the palmar side of the right hand, along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the thumb. Examination of both hands shows following findings. Which of the following structures, when affected, lead to this presentation?
questions.solution:
• The most likely nerve injured here is the median nerve, which occurs in Carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome is the most common entrapment mononeuropathy caused by compression of the median nerve as it passes through the fibro-Osseous carpal tunnel beneath the flexor retinaculum.
  • Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the lateral 3 and a half digits.
Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 297, 298, 303.

questions.text: Patient presented with a twisting injury of the knee. Identify the test being performed.
questions.solution:
The image shows an examination being performed with the knee flexed to about 20 degrees which indicates that it is the Lachman test.
The presence of free gliding indicates that it is a positive Lachman test.

* Lachman test: The patient s knee is flexed to 20 degrees. The lower part of the thigh is grasped with one hand and the upper part of the leg with the other hand. The joint surfaces are shifted backward and forward upon each other. If the knee is stable, there should be no gliding. The presence of gliding indicates the laxity of the anterior cruciate ligament.

Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 574, 575.

questions.text: A child presented with failure to thrive and recurrent infections. On examination, tonsils are absent. Further evaluation confirms the deficiency of adenosine deaminase. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) due to a deficiency of adenosine deaminase.
  • Affected children present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive.
  • Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft- versus-host disease (GVHD).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: A child presented with watery diarrhea and dehydration. There was no blood in the stools. A stool examination revealed following pattern. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario along with the electron micrograph image of the stool sample showing a spoke wheel pattern with complaints of non-bloody diarrhea and dehydration in a child is suggestive of rotavirus.
  • Rotavirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded (ds) RNA virus.
  • Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them.
  • It has 11 segments of double-stranded RNA. They exhibit genetic re assortment due to the presence of this segmented RNA.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 564.

questions.text: A 2 days baby presented with a difficulty in breathing. Auscultation of the chest revealed gurgling sounds and heart sounds shifted to the right. Which among the following is the most common location for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Congenital diaphragmatic hernia with the features given in the clinical vignette occurs most commonly in a left posterolateral defect.
  • Bochdalek hernia is the most common congenital diaphragmatic hernia which occurs on the left posterolateral side due to a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane.
  • The abdominal contents in the thorax compress the developing lungs causing pulmonary hypoplasia which manifests as respiratory distress in most infants.
  • Chest X-ray shows an indistinct diaphragm with radiolucent para cardiac shadow and absent bowel loops in the abdomen.
  • Opacities can be seen in the thorax if solid organs or omentum also herniate. Surgical repair is indicated in all cases either by a thoracic or abdominal approach
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page No 1863, 1864.

questions.text: ldentify the condition shown in the image:
questions.solution:
The MRI image in the question shows downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, which is characteristic of Chiari type 1 malformation.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 27th Edition, Page No 484, 661, 668.
